seo.title: Ackee Alternative: Why Teams Choose OpenPanel
seo.description: Compare OpenPanel vs Ackee Analytics. Discover why teams choose OpenPanel as their Ackee alternative for product analytics, user identification, and scalable analytics while maintaining privacy.

hero.heading: Ackee Alternative
hero.subheading: Love Ackee's privacy-first approach and self-hosting simplicity? OpenPanel adds product analytics capabilities - funnels, cohorts, retention, and user identification - with a modern architecture built for scale.

competitor.name: Ackee
competitor.short_description: Minimalist, self-hosted, privacy-focused web analytics with anonymous tracking and a clean interface.

summary_comparison.title: OpenPanel vs Ackee: Which is right for you?
summary_comparison.intro: Both are privacy-focused open source analytics tools. Ackee focuses on simple web metrics with anonymous tracking. OpenPanel adds product analytics capabilities with user identification.
summary_comparison.one_liner: Ackee is ultra-minimal web analytics; OpenPanel adds product analytics features like funnels, retention, and user identification.
best_for_openpanel: Teams needing product analytics (funnels, retention, cohorts)
Apps requiring user identification and tracking
Projects that need to scale with ClickHouse architecture
Mobile app analytics with native iOS, Android, React Native SDKs
best_for_competitor: Personal blogs and small sites wanting simple stats
Privacy maximalists who want zero user identification
Developers comfortable with GraphQL API customization
Sites that can run on MongoDB for analytics

highlights.title: Key differences at a glance
highlights.intro: Here's how OpenPanel and Ackee compare on the factors that matter most.

items.label: Analytics Depth
items.notes: OpenPanel combines web analytics with product analytics - funnels, retention, cohorts, and user profiles. Ackee provides essential web metrics like page views, referrers, and durations.

items.label: User Identification
items.notes: OpenPanel lets you identify and track individual users across sessions. Ackee intentionally anonymizes all data and cannot track returning users for individual pages.

items.label: Database Architecture
items.notes: OpenPanel uses ClickHouse, purpose-built for analytical queries. Ackee uses MongoDB, which works well for small sites but may struggle with high-volume analytics workloads.

items.label: Deployment Options
items.notes: OpenPanel offers both managed cloud and self-hosted options. Ackee is self-hosted only - you must run your own server and MongoDB instance.

items.label: Open Source
items.notes: Both platforms are fully open source under the MIT license, allowing complete code inspection and modification.

migration.title: Migrating from Ackee to OpenPanel
migration.intro: Switching from Ackee to OpenPanel is straightforward. Both are lightweight with similar integration approaches.

steps.title: Install OpenPanel SDK
steps.description: Add the OpenPanel SDK to your application. Replace the ackee-tracker script with OpenPanel's lightweight tracking code.

steps.title: Map Events to OpenPanel
steps.description: Ackee events translate to OpenPanel events. Replace instance.action() calls with op.track() - the structure is similar.

steps.title: Add User Identification (New)
steps.description: Unlike Ackee, OpenPanel can identify users. Add op.identify() calls to unlock retention, cohorts, and user profiles - a major upgrade from Ackee's anonymous-only model.

steps.title: Configure Dashboards
steps.description: Set up your OpenPanel dashboards. You'll now have access to funnels, retention charts, and cohort analysis that weren't possible in Ackee.

steps.title: Remove Ackee
steps.description: Once verified, remove the Ackee tracker script and optionally decommission your Ackee server and MongoDB instance.

sdk_compatibility.notes: Both use simple event tracking APIs. Ackee's instance.action() becomes OpenPanel's op.track().

historical_data.notes: Ackee intentionally anonymizes data, making historical import challenging. Most teams start fresh with OpenPanel.

faqs.title: Frequently asked questions
faqs.intro: Common questions about switching from Ackee to OpenPanel.

items.question: Is OpenPanel as privacy-friendly as Ackee?
items.answer: Yes! Both are cookie-free by default and can be GDPR compliant without consent banners. The key difference is that OpenPanel allows optional user identification for product analytics, while Ackee is strictly anonymous. You control whether to identify users in OpenPanel.

items.question: Why switch from Ackee to OpenPanel?
items.answer: Teams typically switch when they need: product analytics (funnels, retention, cohorts), user identification, a managed cloud option, mobile SDKs, or a database optimized for analytics. Ackee excels at simple, anonymous web stats but lacks these capabilities.

items.question: Is Ackee really free?
items.answer: Yes, Ackee itself is 100% free and open source. However, you must pay for your own hosting - a server to run Ackee and MongoDB. Using free tiers (Vercel + MongoDB Atlas 512MB), you can run Ackee at zero cost for small sites.

items.question: Does OpenPanel have a GraphQL API like Ackee?
items.answer: No, OpenPanel uses a REST API while Ackee uses GraphQL. Both approaches allow building custom tools and integrations. Ackee's entire UI is powered by its GraphQL API, making it very extensible.

items.question: Can Ackee track mobile apps?
items.answer: Not officially. Ackee is designed for web analytics. There's a community Dart/Flutter package, but no official iOS or Android SDKs. OpenPanel offers native mobile SDKs with full product analytics.

items.question: What will I lose switching from Ackee?
items.answer: Ackee's GraphQL API (OpenPanel uses REST), the ability to host on platforms like Vercel/Netlify as serverless functions, and the community plugins like Svelte and Angular integrations. You'll gain product analytics, user identification, and a managed cloud option.

items.question: How does the database compare?
items.answer: Ackee uses MongoDB (general-purpose document database) while OpenPanel uses ClickHouse (columnar database optimized for analytics). ClickHouse is significantly faster for analytical queries, especially at scale.

items.question: Can Ackee track unique visitors?
items.answer: Yes, but with limitations. Ackee uses a daily-rotating salt hash (IP + user-agent + domain + salt) to identify visitors within a single day. It cannot track returning visitors across days or track unique views per page - this is by design for privacy.
